text: <@U01S26AACSD> has joined the channel

Glad not to be taking on these liabilities now :joy:

<https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/horse-racing/56435950>

attachments.fallback: [February 26th, 2021 6:34 PM] oliverashleyvarney: "As with previous years there can often be trainer/jockey multiples which inevitably gain traction as the runners are confirmed and the shorter priced runners roll up. We do get contact from the trading team to assist in offsetting the liability and will get in contact with Premium accounts to see if they would take some of that risk. If you would be in the position to offer this,please get in contact with your account manager to register your interest"
attachments.text: "As with previous years there can often be trainer/jockey multiples which inevitably gain traction as the runners are confirmed and the shorter priced runners roll up. We do get contact from the trading team to assist in offsetting the liability and will get in contact with Premium accounts to see if they would take some of that risk. If you would be in the position to offer this,please get in contact with your account manager to register your interest"

attachments.title: Cheltenham punter wins at least £250,000
attachments.text: A punter will win at least £250,000 from a £5 bet after deciding to cash out on the final leg of his accumulator at Cheltenham.
attachments.fallback: BBC Sport: Cheltenham punter wins at least £250,000

text: are you implying that there will always be a tennis expertise layer that the market price takes into account, which can't be replicated by the models? Or that the best model is already out there, and it is impossible to beat? (second option seems very doubtful to me)

text: does anyone here use elo, trueskill, or other similar setups to try to predict outcomes?

elements.text: does anyone here use elo, trueskill, or other similar setups to try to predict outcomes?

text: My stuff in the past hasn't been that sort of thing, but I have a friend who is interested in betting on wins and losses, and it seems like the logical sort of thing to use to start going about that?

elements.text: My stuff in the past hasn't been that sort of thing, but I have a friend who is interested in betting on wins and losses, and it seems like the logical sort of thing to use to start going about that?

text: Not currently but I have in the past

text: Trueskill feels really intuitive to me, slash matches how i think about the world more, elo feels hacky, any thing else out there i should consider?

elements.text: Trueskill feels really intuitive to me, slash matches how i think about the world more, elo feels hacky, any thing else out there i should consider?

text: is trueskill not very popular out of curiosity? any sense of that? the only r package i could find looked pretty shit, and the python one i saw didn't look mindblowing either

elements.text: is trueskill not very popular out of curiosity? any sense of that? the only r package i could find looked pretty shit, and the python one i saw didn't look mindblowing either

text: whereas there are several r elo packages, and one of them looks suuuuper nice. But i just don't think i want elo haha

elements.text: whereas there are several r elo packages, and one of them looks suuuuper nice. But i just don't think i want elo haha

text: oh thank god, glicko has an sd it looks like right?

text: Details of TrueSkill are too opaque. Easy to update the ratings but almost impossible to work out how to make predictions from them

elements.text: Details of TrueSkill are too opaque. Easy to update the ratings but almost impossible to work out how to make predictions from them

text: thats the main problem with elo it seems, main reason why trueskill sounded better

elements.text: thats the main problem with elo it seems, main reason why trueskill sounded better

text: intuitively i really like the idea of increasing sd under circumstances, but regressing back towards the mean in elo sounded dumb

elements.text: intuitively i really like the idea of increasing sd under circumstances, but regressing back towards the mean in elo sounded dumb

text: i also think i might like the idea of something that can look backwards, which seems like a big advantage of a logit vs. elo. The logit just looks at all the data you have, obviously, or whatever, so if A beats B in its first ever game, but then over the next 10 games B is awful, the logit won't care so much about that, but of course ELO will treat that first game as meaningful and ignore the next 10

The logit just looks at all the data you have, obviously, or whatever, so if A beats B in its first ever game, but then over the next 10 games B is awful, the logit won't care so much about that, but of course ELO will treat that first game as meaningful and ignore the next 10

text: You shouldn’t be so dismissive of Elo. Yeah, it has some obvious shortcomings but all models are approximations of reality. Ease of implementation is an important consideration. I think the 80/20 rule applies here

elements.text: You shouldn’t be so dismissive of Elo. Yeah, it has some obvious shortcomings but all models are approximations of reality. Ease of implementation is an important consideration. I think the 80/20 rule applies here

text: ah don't get me wrong, i'm not trying to totally dismiss it. I did already do some implementing, but I just really would like the freedom to test theories vis-a-vis those factors

elements.text: ah don't get me wrong, i'm not trying to totally dismiss it. I did already do some implementing, but I just really would like the freedom to test theories vis-a-vis those factors
